Electrostatic Energy Per Ion of a Cubic Crystal

statement.p: A cubic crystal has oppositely charged ions at adjacent corners of a cube. One such cube is shown in the figure. Find electrostatic energy of this cube per ion in units of \text{J} and in \text{eV}. Here, charge is equal to the electronic charge, q=e and side a = 5.64\times 10^{-10}\text{ m}. These are the data of \text{Na}^{+}\text{Cl}^{-} crystal.

hint.p: Label the charges and then organize pairs of same distances.

solution.p: We will label the charges so that we can write down the unique pairs and work out their distances, which go directly into the sum that gives electrostatic energy. The following figure shows my choice.

We find that we have three types of distances, (i) edge, r = a , (ii) face diagonal, r = a \sqrt{2}, and (iii) body diagnal, r = a\sqrt{3} . There are 12 adjacent pairs of opposite charges, 12 face diagonals of similar type charges, and 4 body diagonals of opposite types. Therefore, the sum over potential energies of all pairs gives
U_8 \amp = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{q^2}{a} \left( -12 + \dfrac{12}{\sqrt{2}} - \dfrac{4}{\sqrt{3}} \right). \amp = - 2.4\times 10^{-17}\text{ J} = -14.9\text{ eV}.
We want electrostatic energy per ion, so we divide this by 8.
U = \dfrac{U_8}{8} = -3.0\times 10^{-18}\text{ J} = -1.86\text{ eV}.

problem.title: Potential of Two Parallel Line Charges

statement.p: Two oppositely charged infinitely long wires are placed parallel to each other as shown in . Let wires be parallel to the x-axis. Let the wire with charge density +\lambda cross y axis at y=+a and that with charge density -\lambda cross y axis at y=-a. What is the potential at an arbitray point P(y,z) in the yz-plane?

solution.p:
Let \phi_\pm be the potentials from \pm\lambda. Then, the net potential at P will be
\phi_P = \phi_+ + \phi_-.
Now, potential \phi_+ is already known to be
\phi_+ = \frac{\lambda}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\ln \dfrac{s}{s_\text{ref}}.
Let reference zero be at origin, which will make s_\text{ref} = a from the positive wire. The distance to P is s= \sqrt{(y-a)^2 + z^2}. Therefore, we have
\phi_+ = \frac{\lambda}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\ln \dfrac{\sqrt{(y-a)^2 + z^2}}{a}.
Similarly, we will get the following using the same reference point.
\phi_+ = -\frac{\lambda}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\ln \dfrac{\sqrt{(y+a)^2 + z^2}}{a}.
Note: we must use the same reference point for all charges in one situation. Now, we can add them to get
\phi_P = \frac{\lambda}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \ln \dfrac{ (y-a)^2 + z^2}{ (y+a)^2 + z^2}.

problem.title: Potential of Two Overlapping Spherically Charged Clouds

statement.p: Two spherically charged clouds of equal radius R and opposite charge densities \pm \rho overlap so that their separation distance is a with a \lt 2R. Find the electric potentials (a) at a point outside the clouds, (b) at a point where the clouds overlap, and (c) at a point inside the positive cloud which is not in the overlap zone. Use to express your answer.

answer.p: (a) \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\left(\frac{1}{r_1} - \frac{1}{\sqrt{r_1^2 + a^2 + 2 r_1 a \cos\, \theta_1}} \right), (b) \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q}{2R^3}\left( a^2 + 2 a r_2 \cos\,\theta_2 \right), (c) \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q}{R} \left( \frac{3}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\; \frac{r_{3}^2}{R^2} - \frac{R}{ \sqrt{r_3^2 + a^2 + 2 r_3 a \cos\, \theta_3} } \right).

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) We will use superposition to find the net potentials. We need the distance of the field point P_1 from the centers of the two spheres. Let us call these distances r_\pm.
r_+ \amp = r_1 r_- \amp = \sqrt{r_1^2 + a^2 - 2 r_1 a \cos(\pi - \theta_1)} \amp = \sqrt{r_1^2 + a^2 + 2 r_1 a \cos\, \theta_1}
Let total charges on the spheres be \pm q = \pm\dfrac{4}{3}\pi R^3 \rho. Then, we have the following for the net potential at P_1.
\phi_1 \amp = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\left(\frac{1}{r_+} - \frac{1}{r_-} \right) \amp = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\left(\frac{1}{r_1} - \frac{1}{\sqrt{r_1^2 + a^2 + 2 r_1 a \cos\, \theta_1}} \right)

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) Here, point is inside point for both clouds. Therefore, we will use the inside formulas when superposing them. The distances are
r_+ \amp = r_2 r_- \amp = \sqrt{r_2^2 + a^2 - 2 r_2 a \cos(\pi - \theta_2)} \amp = \sqrt{r_2^2 + a^2 + 2 r_2 a \cos\, \theta_2}
Using the same q as in (a), we have the following for the net potential at P_2.
\phi_2 \amp = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q}{R} \left( \frac{3}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\; \frac{r_{+}^2}{R^2} \right) - \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q}{R} \left( \frac{3}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\; \frac{r_{-}^2}{R^2} \right) \amp = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q}{2R^3}\left( -r_{+}^2 + r_{-}^2\right) = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q}{2R^3}\left( a^2 + 2 a r_2 \cos\,\theta_2 \right).

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) Now, the point is an inside point for the positive cloud and an outside point for the negative cloud. This will give
\phi_3 \amp = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q}{R} \left( \frac{3}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\; \frac{r_{+}^2}{R^2} \right) - \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q}{r_{-}},
with
r_+ \amp = r_3,\ \ r_- = \sqrt{r_3^2 + a^2 + 2 r_3 a \cos\, \theta_3}.
Writing the potential explicitly, we have
\phi_3 = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q}{R} \left( \frac{3}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\; \frac{r_{3}^2}{R^2} - \frac{R}{ \sqrt{r_3^2 + a^2 + 2 r_3 a \cos\, \theta_3} } \right).
